article:
:For other uses, see [[Libertarian (disambiguation)]] and [[Libertarianism
(disambiguation)]]


'Libertarianism' (Latin: liber, "free") [http://www.libertarianism.org/ex-
3.html Libertarianism.org. "A Note on Labels: Why 'Libertarian'?"], Cato
Institute projected, accessed July 4, 2013. is a set of related political
philosophies that uphold liberty as the highest political end. Rothbard,
Murray N. (1979). "Myth and Truth About Libertarianism," LewRockwell.com,
[http://www.lewrockwell.com/rothbard/rothbard168.html] Rothbard,
Murray N. (1982). [[The Ethics of Liberty]], Mises.org
[http://mises.org/rothbard/ethics/thirty.asp] This includes emphasis on
the primacy of individual liberty, [[EncyclopÃ¦dia
Britannica]]. "Libertarianism," [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/3393-
21/libertarianism] [[Journal of Libertarian Studies|The Journal of
Libertarian Studies]], 11:2 (Summer 1995): 132â181
[http://mises.org/journals/jls/11_2/11_2_5.pdf] political freedom, and
voluntary association. It is the antonym to authoritarianism. J. J. Ray
(1980). "Libertarians and the Authoritarian Personality," [[Journal of
Libertarian Studies|The Journal of Libertarian Studies]], Vol. IV, No. 1
[https://mises.org/journals/jls/4_1/4_1_2.pdf] Libertarians advocate a
society with minimized government or no government at all. Friedman, David D. (2008). "libertarianism," [[The New
Palgrave Dictionary of Economics]], 2nd Edition, [http://www.dictionaryofeconom-
ics.com/article?id=pde2008_L000227&edition=all&field=content&q= Abstract];
Quote: "Libertarians differ among themselves in the degree to which they rely on
rights-based or consequentialist arguments and on how far they take their
conclusions, ranging from classical liberals, who wish only to drastically
reduce government, to anarcho-capitalists who would replace all useful
government functions with private alternatives." Ronald Hamowy, The
Encyclopedia of Libertarianism, Chapter: "Anarchism", pp. 10â13; Quote:
"Libertarianism puts severe limits on morally permissible government action. If
one takes its strictures seriously, does libertarianism require the abolition of
government, logically reducing the position to anarchism? Robert Nozick
effectively captures this dilemma: âIndividucals have rights, and there are
things no person or group may do to them (without violating their rights). So
strong and far-reaching are these rights that they raise the question of what,
if anything, the state and its official may do.â Libertarian political
philsophers have extensively debated this question, and many concude that the
answer is âNothingâ.â Paul F. Downton, Ecopolis: Architecture and
Cities for a Changing Climate, Volume 1 of Future City, Springer, 2008, [http:/-
/books.google.com/books?id=iDhbMM5ms6QC&pg=PA157&dq=state+%22libertarian+munici-
palism%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2HHXUb7ANNj94APHwYHYBw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=stat-
e%20%22libertarian%20municipalism%22&f=false p. 157] , ISBN 1402084951 Quote:
âTaking this idea forward to look at how governance would work without the
apparatus of the central state, Bookchin proposed a 'libertarian municipalism'
in opposition to statism.â

In the [[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]], Peter Vallentyne defines
libertarianism as the moral view that agents initially fully own themselves and
have certain moral powers to acquire property rights in external
things. Libertarian philosopher Roderick Long defines libertarianism
as "any political position that advocates a radical redistribution of power from
the coercive state to voluntary associations of free individuals", whether
"voluntary association" takes the form of the free market or of communal co-
operatives. According
to the U.S. Libertarian Party, libertarianism is the advocacy of a government
that is funded voluntarily and limited to protecting individuals from coercion
and violence. Watts, Duncan (2002). Understanding American government and
politics: a guide for A2 politics students. Manchester, UK: Manchester
University Press. p. 246.

Libertarian schools of thought differ over the degree to which the state should
have a role. Anarchist schools advocate complete
elimination of the state, while Minarchist schools advocate a state which is
limited to protecting its citizens from aggression, theft, breach of contract,
and fraud. Some schools accept governmental assistance for the poor.
Additionally, some schools are supportive of private property rights in the
ownership of unappropriated land and natural resources, while others reject such
private ownership and support various forms of left-
libertarianism. ;
